questions.prompt: A loop invariant must be true at which points?
options: Only at the start of the loop
At initialization, before each iteration, and at termination
Only when the loop counter is even
Only at the end of the loop
questions.explanation: Loop invariants must hold at initialization, be maintained by each iteration, and imply correctness at termination.

questions.prompt: "It works for all my test cases" is a valid proof of correctness.
questions.explanation: Testing shows presence of bugs, not absence. A proof must hold for ALL possible inputs.

questions.prompt: To prove a recursive algorithm correct, which technique is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Induction mirrors recursion: prove base case, assume works for smaller inputs, prove it works for current input.

questions.prompt: For Insertion Sort, a good loop invariant is:
options: arr[0..i-1] contains the original elements in sorted order
questions.explanation: At each iteration, the subarray arr[0..i-1] is sorted and contains the original elements from those positions.

questions.prompt: The three parts of a loop invariant proof are: Initialization, ______, and Termination.
questions.explanation: Maintenance shows that if the invariant holds before an iteration, it holds after the iteration too.

questions.prompt: What does P stand for in complexity theory?
questions.explanation: P is the class of problems solvable in polynomial time O(n^k) for some constant k.
NP means Nondeterministic Polynomial - problems whose solutions can be verified in polynomial time.

questions.prompt: Every problem in P is also in NP.
questions.explanation: If you can solve a problem in polynomial time, you can certainly verify a solution in polynomial time. P ⊆ NP.

questions.prompt: If P = NP, what would it mean?
options: All NP problems would have polynomial-time solutions
questions.explanation: P = NP would mean every problem with efficiently verifiable solutions also has efficient solutions.

questions.prompt: NP-Complete problems are the ______ problems in NP.
questions.explanation: NP-Complete problems are at least as hard as any problem in NP. Solving one efficiently would solve all of NP.

questions.prompt: Which of these is an NP-Complete problem?
questions.explanation: Traveling Salesman (decision version: is there a tour ≤ k?) is a classic NP-Complete problem.

questions.prompt: What is a reduction in complexity theory?
questions.explanation: A reduction transforms problem A into problem B, showing that solving B would solve A.

questions.prompt: If problem A reduces to problem B in polynomial time, and B is in P, then A is in P.
questions.explanation: We can transform A to B in poly-time, solve B in poly-time, giving a poly-time solution for A.

questions.prompt: What should you do if you identify a problem as NP-Complete?
options: Keep trying to find an O(n^2) solution
Give up on the problem entirely
questions.explanation: For NP-Complete problems, use approximations, heuristics, or special-case solutions instead of exact algorithms.

options: It can be solved in linear time
It was the first problem proven NP-Complete
questions.explanation: SAT was proven NP-Complete by Cook in 1971, establishing the foundation of NP-Completeness theory.
